comments.commentBody: Thank you Kevin. President Obama, Secretary Hilary Clinton and now Secretary John Kerry have tried their utmost to reverse and muscular foreign policy exhibited by 8 years of Bush and his cronies. It is not an easy task and it is also a thankless job, no one appreciates all the work that goes on behind doors in the diplomacy quarters. Americans wanted shock and awe and they got it from a cowboy in hat. But now, Americans are more worried about their own jobs, health care, education - they should stop meddling and interfering with other countries' affairs, stop manipulating the globe when what they need most is an authentic, genuine leader who cares about our children and the planet.

George Bush was bad enough:  he got us into an endless war on terrorism.  The terrorists had no nuclear weapons.  Now Rubio wants to get us into a war with Russia and/or China.  They have nuclear weapons.  Rubio is even worse than Bush.

Just what we need -- another war enthusiast, self-proclaimed devotee of the Prince of Peace. Another chickenhawk with the strength to get votes by sending our brave soldiers to die without hesitation, but not serve himself. Another politician who feels it morally right to take our Social Security & food stamps from the budget, but wants to pour a trillion dollars into unnecessary war, war-profiteers, and the military-industrial complex, while the rich get war-time tax breaks. I have much more respect for Ron Paul than Rubio.

A freedom to be put down if certain conditions are met (as decided by the individual in a health will) must override the desire for hospitals and insurance companies to profit by keeping us alive, by milking the government, and as a nation stealing from future generations, and from a family who will agonize over such decisions.

Interesting -- as I was reading this story, my mind immediately started thinking, "How can I avoid this kind of hell?". The last thing I want is to be tube-fed, trached, diapered, etc. And yet, we live in a society that doesn't allow us to say, please, just let me die and be at peace. At least they don't allow us (or anyone else) to act on that thought.

I had a friend who recently made the decision to quit dialysis and turn his pacemaker off. He died within two days. I envied his ability to control the timing of his death. It is a right we all should have, one way or the other. One key way to make sure you do have control is to avoid hospitalization or nursing homes, where health care providers will do everything to keep a person alive rather than respect written directives or patient's verbal orders.

As others point out, private insurance companies and health care facilities who must make profits for investors have no moral place in health care. This is a We The People responsibility.

This sounds like a nightmare I have once in awhile. I am so ill that I can't take care of myself and forced to keep living instead of allowed to die. I wouldn't wish that situation on my worst enemy. "Long-term care" is my euphemism for hell on earth...

I have told everyone I know to please "put me down" like you would a family dog if I cannot do it myself. I pray that I am able to do it myself....

Half truths are sometimes worse that an outright lie; cherry-picking data from various sources and then publishing incomplete and disingenuous reports not supported by evidence is dishonest; and harms the virgin ears of Ryan's fellow republicans that are ignorant of the facts. Trusting too much the knowledge of Mr. Ryan and voting on it, without doing your homework is dangerous to your and your constituents' health and interests. Our capitalistic system, along its advantages, also carries the distinct risk of leaving the disadvantaged poor worse off; and, with no fault of their own, stuck to jobs with no livable wages; or if unemployed, unable to find a new job; hence, obligated to seek help; and part of government's job is to extend a safety social net to those in need. Trying to castigate the needy, and insulting them as 'hammockers' just adds injury to the insults in Ryan's report. Not a nice picture. Not nice people up there.

May I point out that since the "War On Poverty" the Republicans have declared the "War on the Working Class". If, as you claim, that the percentage of our population that is "poor" is the same as existed in 1964 I am quite surprised.  In view of the Republican assault on the vast numbers of our population, those classified as "poor" must have grown substantially. Surely the success of the anti unionism mantra of the Republicans has deprived the working poor of one of the means by which prior generations had risen into the middle class.  Throwing hundreds of thousands of young black men into jail on minor marijuana offenses has certainly kept innumerable black families in poverty. The cost of those prisons exceeds our budgets for schools and universities; all contributing to the lack of educational opportunities for many of our poorer citizens. Onerous medical expenses have driven many of our fellow citizens into poverty, but one of the answers to this vicious cycle, universal health care, has been rejected by  the right wing . Senseless Wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have sapped this Country of billions of dollars that could have been used to stimulate innovation and to create jobs for all of us, including the less fortunate. The great recession caused by the greed of the big banks and big corporations has also driven millions into poverty. Those are the reasons poverty still exists in this Country, not because of the meager aid we give to the poor.

If he wants to be hawkish overseas, he darn well better be ready to raise taxes to pay for it AND offer up his own children to fight. The American people are tired of politicians using their children to gain political position.

As to his fears of those criticizing him for wanting immigration reform -- it was not that long ago red states such as Utah were demanding immigration reform. Of course, that was before Obama was for it.
Rubio Bush: "There's got to be another country somewhere that we can invade."  Yup, let's invade Russia; good idea.  Bush didn't quite destroy the US, much as he tried.  Maybe Rubio can do it!

I am pretty sure that he (and it will be "he") is required to take a hawkish stance on foreign policy. This is right before he kisses the ring. It's part of the "big tent" policy that is working so well-as long as you are an older white male. The tent is actually getting bigger and bigger as more and more people leave.

Sorry Marco, a "muscular foreign policy" might play well inside the Beltway and at the Carlyle Group, but the American public is sick to death of our "leaders" wasting trillions halfway around the world on fights that pose no danger to the US (e.g. Vietnam, Iraq, Iran, Egypt, Syria, Ukraine, etc.).

Instead of advocating throwing yet more more money at foreign countries, how about spending here in the USA, like on infrastructure, jobs, health care? You know, things that make all our lives better instead of enriching a few already too fat cats.
Why, he's every bit as much an expert on foreign policy as George W. Bush was.  And that never phased the voting public.

Rubio is an inexperienced individual trying to make a name for himself by an incursion into international waters he has no knowledge whatsoever, just a brush-up in theory; and, hopefully, to attack Obama in whatever he can, so he is viewed more favorably by his comrades-in-arms, his fellow republicans. I see a lot of bluster but no humility for his shortcomings, not a good start, no good ending either.

Just who is going to pay for another war?
America is broke, the veterans are being denied benefits by the Republicans in Congress and the bloody infrastructure is crumbling around our ankles.
Are conservatives blind, stupid or just plain self-serving? Are they in total denial and abjuring reality?
I think the clown in the flag shorts is a perfect metaphor for the Republican party with just the right touch of whimsy twinned with a soupçon of support for gay rights!
Do these phonies care about anything besides taking orders and directions from the Koch boys?
I find the photo interesting in it's complete lack of women. I guess they lost their "binders full of women"!

Every time a Republican, or a Democrat for that matter, decries the bloodless "invasion" of Crimea a reporter should be right in their face with one word, IRAQ.  And anytime a Republican calls for a more muscular foreign policy a reporter should be right in their face asking them what they mean.  War?  Would they bring this country into yet another war?

The politicians of today will take whatever position they may find would benefit  them the most regarding the above two choices. let's not forget the third choice so aptly subscribed by Mr. Cruz, reincarnation of Ronald Reagan.

So back to the cold war days and trillions of dollars in military spending? I think Mr. Rubio is just another opportunistic politician taking advantage of a crisis for personal gain.   a strong backer of Senator Cruz?  His Presidential train has left the station and he was not on it.

Today's ONION's headline says:
DOLAN DOLES OUT A CHAMPIONSHIP RING FOR THE KNICKS: Tired with losing, the beleaguered chairman of the Knicks organization decided to take the coaching job himself. Miraculously, the Knicks, in the middle of a horrible season, won their last 20 games and made the playoffs, beat MIAMI and INDIANA and swept the SPURS in the finals. Remarkably, the KNICKS got unexpected help from Jeff Van Gundy, who as an improvised point guard, "hogged" the opponents' legs, and from Latrell Sprewell, who came back from retirement to grab the neck of opponents' coaches.
This story was rejected as too farcical by The Onion.

Exactly, the Crimean issue is totally made up by Putin's propaganda to justify invasion and annexation. There are many ethnic Russians in Crimea who do not want to be annexed to Russian Federation. Not to mention Ukrainians and Crimean Tatars, who are native to the area but were formerly driven away by Russian Communists. People lived peacefully in Crimea until recently Kremlin has launched a brutal media propaganda campaign about coming "atrocities" from the West and how bad European Union is because there are "fascists" there. Sadly, some people were swayed by the propaganda....
Read your last paragraph.

As much as I hate the current Russian "protection" of Crimea, perhaps the closest precedent I can think of is Kosovo. NATO fought a brief war to protect the majority Albanians there (the Russians said "occupy" and "interfere in the internal affairs"). Then, while still under Western protections, the people of Kosovo had a referendum in which they decided to be independent of Serbia - an independence that was immediately recognized by most Western governments. Serbia and Russia strenuously protested that this was not only against the Serbian constitution, and against international norms, but also that Kosovo had always been a historical part of Serbia, and in fact part of the Serbian ancient heartland, which had only become majority Albanian relatively recently. In other words, the West was interfering in the "territorial integrity" of Serbia.

By comparison, the current Russian occupation (or "protection", as the Russians put it) of Crimea and its majority Russian population is relatively non-violent so far. Also, Crimea was not historically part of Ukraine. Any referendum for independence that will take place there will be as legitimate or illegitimate as the one in Kosovo in my opinion.

The main difference is that Serbia was committing actual war crimes in Kosovo, whereas the presumed threat to Crimea from the new government in Kiev is essentially hypothetical and non-existing.

"making antipoverty programs much more generous would indeed reduce the incentive to work..But why, exactly, should that be such a concern?"

The Republicans problem is they've been too successful at impoverishing ordinary working Americans.

Way back in 1980, when Reagan became president and the Republicans achieved ascendancy, America had a large middle class. Back then Republicans could bash aid recipients without worrying about offending half the electorate. Today if you bash them you offend 47% and more as many of the remaining "middle class" are working on contract so they must build into their expectations that they are subject to easy layoffs, thus future aid recipients.

Message aside, Republicans haven't changed who they are: they are for the ever greater concentration of wealth and power.

The way they achieve this is by attacking other groups bargaining power: unions for workers, affordable quality education for middle class, even ACORN for the very poor. No stone is unturned.

"Ryan would have us believe that the “hammock” created by the social safety net is the reason so many Americans remain trapped in poverty" but the real source of poverty is lack of bargaining power.

In this light, Ryan's real objection to public aid is that it gives bargaining power to the poor, which means they are less desperate and so don't have to accept the most degrading wage offered.

They've been so successful that they have to change their message to concern for the poor. Right.

No, America is not up in arms over this rational movement by Putin to offset a right wing coup by nationalists. Some propagandized Americans are, because they are hammers who only see nails.

Your admiration of Obama is misplaced, he's totally bungled this situation, both committing us to wasteful spending, and alienating a leader who's the only player with any cards.

Russians don't want re-building of the USSR or Russian Empire. I do believe that every Russian wants a peice.
But every Russian has a history classes in school. Every Russian knows what is Crimea and what is "mistake" of Khruschev. Every Russian what was done in Kosovo, in Iraq, in Lybia, in Afganistan (to see the ties between Serbia and RUssia just look at the history or visit football match Serbia - Russia).
I'm 24 year old young man with highest education, I've been to Europe and the US, I believed in democracy, freedom, good will of the US and EU.
Now I still believe in democracy and freedom, but I'm sure big countries just fight for their interests using double-standards.

Well, it's time to face the real world. No matter where our stock market index goes, if we can protect our interests without blood that's the good price.

If most of the Crimean people want to secede from the Ukraine and join Russia for stability, security and economic reasons, if more than 51% of the people vote this way then that is what should happen. This is called democracy! The majority of the people get to determine the destiny of the society that they live in. The President of the USA or any other place really has nothing to say about  any of this because it has nothing directly to do with the USA.  The Ukraine once voted to secede from the former Soviet Union and the new Russia and now the Crimeans want to secede from the Ukraine and go back to Russia. And so the world turns. No one knows what is better for their country then the people who live there. And if they make mistakes then it is their mistakes not anyone elses like the ones we made in Iraq and Afghanistan, and Vietnam, Cambodia now there's a real good example of punishing a foreign people with weapons of mass destruction. Who are we to judge these things? Does Pres. Obama and the state department really thinkw we are that stupid or have some kind of amnesia?

There's a difference between a civil war and aggression directed from one country towards another.

In 1941 Nazi Germany attacked France. Not a civil war, just a war and occupation.
In 2014 Russia attacked Ukraine. Not a civil war, just a war and occupation.

U.S. and Britain are allies with Ukraine as well as the European Union. Things are being dealt with on bases of the international law.

I am not quite sure I understand why USA is getting riled up and involved  in a  civil war of the local population in Crimea. As such USA his having hard time in justifying loss of 3000 or so young Americans in a small country like Afghanistan. Russia is a major power with big nuclear arsenal. Majority population of  Crimea is Russian. I think we should sit back, relax and observe what plays out there --- let the European Union  talk to the Russians/Ukrainians and play a role, if any.

Yugoslavia was not attacked and occupied by another country. In Ukrainian Crimea, Russia has sent its troops to occupy a sovereign territory of Ukraine, in violation of international laws and agreements. This is very different from Kosovo.

@Yurko, My point is that the official stated US position is that a referendum of the residents of the Crimea is illegal because it is in violation of the Ukraine constitution. I recognize that position as inconsistent, and postulate that the underlying reasons for it are self-serving.

Our own constitution requires certain procedures for wars. We don't follow them and have not declared war since WWII. Our various invasions and military adventures since then have all been extra-legal in that sense. Do we care? Apparently not.

My recollection is that we were fine with Kosovo declaring its sovereignty, despite its separation from Serbia being in pretty clear violation of the Serbian constitution.

Personally, I doubt whether it is possible to be entirely consistent in matters where local self-governance conflicts with more broadly established laws. We all know that laws can sometimes be abominable and may be at odds with liberty and local rule. Sometimes freedom fighters (or voters) get approval for declaring independence, other times they are rejected. The history of outsiders' concerns with other country's sovereignty is more often about self-interest than legal concepts, or even human rights.

@Steve Bolger — It was arbitrary, but perfectly legal under the Soviet Constitution, and ratified by Soviet authorities. When the USSR collapsed, the leadership of all these states agreed to lay these claims to rest, because changing the boundaries risked massive conflict. And Russia pledged to respect Ukraine's territorial integrity under treaty, and in exchange for Ukraine giving up nuclear weapons.

Moreover, under international law and the UN charter, countries cannot change their boundaries by force, and typically, regions can only secede (and get international recognition) if that secession is recognized by the state. This is a key feature of the global security order post-WWII, and is precisely to avoid these types of landgrabs.

The reason the successor states of the USSR, Czechoslovakia, and Yugoslavia were recognized was because the constitutions of those states permitted states to secede unilaterally. The Ukrainian constitution permits secession if the whole country - by way of referendum or parliament approves. That isn't the case here.

Regardless, perhaps a status referendum, under international supervision, for Crimea would be prudent. But surely you can see that a rapid referendum under Russian military occupation isn't exactly free or fair?

This is a war declared by Russia against Ukraine. Russia has nuclear warheads. In 1994 Ukraine, at the request of the international community, gave away its nuclear warheads, in exchange of international guarantees of protection of Ukraine's sovereignty and borders. Today Ukrainian borders and sovereignty are violated by Russian invasion. According to the international law, the guarantor countries must intervene.

Why not let Ukraine take care of it's own sovereignty. It is pathetic witnessing the frenetic State Department diplomats and the US president drawing at straws to effect some control in this situation, a thousand miles from home.
Makes one wonder, are the Ukrainians capable of managing their own affairs or do they need US diplomats plotting there every move.
What we may be seeing here is just one more miscalculation by the Washington policy makers.
Put in another way, is the color of the flag that flies in Crimea or Ukraine really going to effect life on this side of the pond?
They certainly can, but there would be very few people there recording a 'yes' vote on those questions. In Crimea the results on 16 March will speak for themselves.

Do you justify Russian military aggression with your statement? Who then will be the next victim on Putin's list? You never now what's on the mind of these little evil liars lurking in Kremlin hallways...

All that whining and handwringing by the West is to no avail. Russia is keeping Crimea and that's all there is to it. The sooner US, EU and the de facto government in Kiev realise that the better it will be for everyone involved. Putin simply could not not do it. Russian people would never forgive him for that.
